item.title: Carbon dioxide supply deal agreed between government and firms
item.description: A deal averting another carbon dioxide crisis in the food and drink industry will now run into 2022.

item.title: Iraq claims capture of IS financial chief in operation abroad
item.description: Sami Jasim al-Jaburi was allegedly a deputy leader of the jihadist group under Abu Bakr al-Baghdadi.

item.title: Pregnant women urged to get Covid vaccine by NHS England
item.description: NHS England says the number of pregnant women seriously ill in critical care with the virus has grown.

item.title: Stephen Port: Detective believed first victim had been murdered
item.description: Stephen Port went on to kill three more young men with overdoses of the date rape drug GHB.

item.title: Covid-19: Pregnant women urged to get jab and PC could lose job for breach
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Monday evening.

item.title: Arrests over 'lookalike' fraudulent passports
item.description: Ten people are detained in London and Kent after an international investigation into false documents.

item.title: Bedfordshire A5 crash: Four feared dead
item.description: Police say they are involved in "highly-complex work" after the crash on the A5.

item.title: Gas price rises: Kwarteng asks Treasury to help firms over cost
item.description: Business Secretary Kwasi Kwarteng requests support for industries hit by soaring energy costs.

item.title: Star Trek's William Shatner on his plan to boldly go into space
item.description: The actor - who plays Captain James T Kirk in the original Star Trek series - is set to go into space for real.

item.title: Asos boss exits as firm warns profits to plunge
item.description: "Normalised" levels of clothing returns are set to hit the online fashion giant's profits.

item.title: Ohio police probed after man screaming 'I'm paraplegic' dragged from car
item.description: An investigation is launched into why Ohio officers pulled out the man as he called for help.

item.title: UK cyber head says Russia responsible for 'devastating' ransomware attacks
item.description: UK security agencies say most of these attacks on the UK come from cyber criminals in Russia.

item.title: Benjamin Mendy: Man City defender refused bail for third time
item.description: The footballer is accused of the rape and sexual assault of three women at his home in Cheshire.

item.title: Malaria vaccine 'will change African lives forever'
item.description: As African countries get the vaccine, Newsbeat speaks to two people who've grown up with Malaria.

item.title: Paul McCartney says John Lennon 'instigated' the Beatles' break-up
item.description: "It was John who wanted a divorce," he says, setting the record straight on the band's break-up.

item.title: Prince Charles: My Aston Martin runs on wine and cheese
item.description: Ahead of COP26, Prince Charles speaks to the BBC about his personal action and decades of campaigning.

item.title: Chris Packham 'not intimidated' by fire attack on home
item.description: The wildlife expert says a suspected arson attack at his home will not stop his environmental campaigning.

item.title: Expelled: Russia, repression and me
item.description: The BBC's Sarah Rainsford reflects on being barred from Russia and the assault on the country's freedoms.

item.title: Marcus Rashford: Manchester United and England striker says support after racist abuse was a 'special moment'
item.description: Marcus Rashford says the support he received after being targeted with racist abuse following the Euro 2020 final was a "special moment" for him.

item.title: The race to save California’s famous sequoia trees
item.description: Tourists flock to California’s famous sequoia trees, but wildfires are threatening their existence.

item.title: Northamptonshire: Thousands attend World Conker Championships
item.description: Jasmine Tetley retained her 2019 title after the 2020 event was cancelled due to Covid.

item.title: The 25-year-old who's been a clown for two decades
item.description: Lucien Santus started performing as a clown when he was four years old.

item.title: 'Why drilling holes in fences can save hedgehogs'
item.description: Jennifer Manning-Ohren is turning her community into a highway to help the endangered creatures.

item.title: Drugs, arms, and terror: A high-profile defector on Kim's North Korea
item.description: A former colonel describes a leadership making cash by any means, from drug factories to illegal arms deals.

item.title: Prince Charles: I understand climate activists' anger
item.description: The Prince of Wales tells the BBC he sympathises with protesters - but any action must be constructive.

item.title: What are the accusations against Prince Andrew?
item.description: Here's what you need to know about the sex abuse claims being pursued by Virginia Giuffre in the US.

item.title: Why are gas prices so high and what is happening to fuel bills?
item.description: Businesses and householders face a rise in energy bills, with some energy suppliers going bust.

item.title: Stealthing: California bans non-consensual condom removal
item.description: Victims of "stealthing" risk sexually transmitted infections and pregnancy. Now they can sue offenders.

item.title: Silenced no more: A new era of tech whistleblowing?
item.description: Frances Haugen's Facebook leaks and the new Silenced No More Act may help others to come forward.

item.title: Are asylum suicides an unfolding national tragedy?
item.description: Campaigners call for an inquiry into the rate of suicides among young asylum seekers in the UK.

item.title: Smart headbands claim to make people calmer. Do they work?
item.description: Devices that measure brainwaves are increasingly being used by athletes to improve their performance.

item.title: Was AQ Khan the most dangerous man in the world?
item.description: Western spies branded AQ Khan as dangerous as bin Laden - but many in Pakistan saw him as a hero.

item.title: Newcastle United takeover: What is PIF, the main owner of the club?
item.description: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund owns 80% of Newcastle after a high-profile takeover.

item.title: Oh Wonder: We spent our honeymoon covered in cockroaches in a burning building
item.description: The indie-pop duo broke up while recording their fourth album, and things only got weirder after that.

item.title: England boss Southgate 'commits crime' every time he picks team
item.description: England boss Gareth Southgate says he "commits a crime" every time he picks a team because of the players he has to leave out - and will make changes for Tuesday's match with Hungary.

item.title: Retiring not in Wilder's plans despite Fury defeat, says heavyweight's trainer
item.description: Heavyweight Deontay Wilder will not be quitting boxing after losing to Tyson Fury for a second time, says trainer Malik Scott.

item.title: Red Bull's Christian Horner questions Mercedes speed gains
item.description: Red Bull's Christian Horner expresses his "surprise" at gains he says Mercedes have made with their engine performance.

item.title: 'If one person watches and says "I need help" that would be a major success story'
item.description: In a new film coming to BBC One, former England footballer Paul Merson investigates his addiction to gambling.

item.title: Newcastle part-owner Staveley meets under-pressure boss Bruce
item.description: Newcastle part-owner Amanda Staveley meets Steve Bruce at the club training ground on Monday with the manager's future still unclear.

item.title: Only swimming & athletics to be compulsory for Commonwealth Games hosts to stage
item.description: The number of compulsory sports that Commonwealth Games hosts will have to stage in future is set to be cut from 16 to just two.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: New travel rules: What are the red list countries and do I need a test?
item.description: The number of red-list countries will be cut to just seven.

item.title: Covid: What are the social distancing rules across the UK?
item.description: Social distancing rules are changing across the UK.

item.title: Can I get a free flu jab?
item.description: Health officials are urging millions of people to get a free flu vaccination before winter.

item.title: Covid passports: How do I get one and when will I need it?
item.description: People in Scotland and Wales will need a Covid passport to go to nightclubs and attend large events.

item.title: 'How I escaped a hidden world of gangs and exploitation'
item.description: Aliyah's smile conceals a lifetime of abuse - and experts warn her experience is all too common among a forgotten group of girls.

item.title: One of the darkest moments in Brazilian football - and the divide that still runs deep
item.description: A home Copa America in 1989 became a flashpoint in north-eastern Brazil's persistent struggles with prejudice and poverty.

item.title: The flood that drowned American dreams
item.description: Immigrant deaths in New York's floods lay bare the 'climate apartheid' wrought by extreme weather.

item.title: In need of modernisation? The UK’s housing crisis close up
item.description: Thousands of people are saving to get on the property ladder - but not everyone who gets on it is a winner. Five stories from the UK’s ever-changing housing market.

item.title: Female Afghan judges hunted by the murderers they convicted
item.description: Six former female judges who have gone into hiding speak to the BBC from secret locations across the country.
